message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Non-invasive malignancy suggests ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Excisional biopsy revealed DCIS, thus a lumpectomy is recommended. Observation alone is not sufficient and radiotherapy and bilateral mastectomy may not be necessary for DCIS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome, which can increase the risk of breast cancer, and a family history of breast cancer. The biopsy result is positive for non-invasive malignancy. Lumpectomy is the most appropriate treatment for non-invasive breast cancer. Observation with mammograms every 6 months or radiotherapy may be options but are not the most appropriate course of treatment. Bilateral mastectomy may be considered in certain cases, but it is not necessary in this case as the cancer is non-invasive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of non-invasive malignancy calls for treatment, and lumpectomy is a common surgical option for this stage of breast cancer. Bilateral mastectomy is not necessary unless the patient has a strong family history or genetic predisposition to breast cancer. Observation alone without treatment is not appropriate. Radiotherapy may be used after lumpectomy to decrease the risk of recurrence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s histologic exam shows evidence of non-invasive malignancy, which suggests the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Lumpectomy is the appropriate course of treatment for patients with DCIS. Options A and B are not appropriate treatment options for DCIS, and option D may be excessive for DCIS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has PCOS and regular menstrual cycles, which indicate that the risk of malignancy is relatively low. The absence of palpable masses or lymphadenopathy also suggests localized non-invasive malignancy. Therefore, lumpectomy is the most appropriate course of treatment. Observations or radiotherapy may not remove all of the cancerous cells, and bilateral mastectomy is not necessary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has evidence of non-invasive malignancy, which is best treated with lumpectomy. Observation or radiotherapy may not be sufficient to remove the malignancy, and a bilateral mastectomy may be too aggressive unless there is a strong family history of breast cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a significant family history of breast cancer, and an excisional biopsy reports non-invasive malignancy. Lumpectomy is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient. Observation alone is not recommended because the patient has evidence of malignancy, and radiotherapy or mastectomy may not be necessary since the cancer is non-invasive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has polycystic ovarian syndrome and the family history of breast cancer, which increases the risk of breast cancer. The biopsy shows a non-invasive malignancy, which is usually treated with lumpectomy followed by radiation therapy. Observation alone is not recommended, and the bilateral mastectomy is an aggressive approach that is usually reserved for high-risk patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of non-invasive malignancy suggests early-stage breast cancer, and lumpectomy is the most appropriate course of treatment. Observation with bilateral mammograms every 6 months may miss the opportunity for early and effective intervention, and radiotherapy or bilateral mastectomy may be unnecessary for a non-invasive malignancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome, which increases the risk for breast cancer. The biopsy shows evidence of non-invasive malignancy, which is treated with lumpectomy. Bilateral mastectomy is not necessary unless there is a high risk of recurrence or a strong family history of breast cancer. Observation or radiotherapy alone are not appropriate treatments for non-invasive malignancy.
